awd_titl_txt: Relative Langlands Program: Periods, Heights and L-functions
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the principal investigator's research on number theory. Number theory has its historical roots in the study of natural numbers. It is among the oldest branches of mathematics. Within the last half century it has become an indispensable tool, with diverse applications in areas such as data transmission and processing, communication systems, and internet security. The PI is one of the organizers of a workshop, the Arizona Winter School. He is also training graduate students in topics related to this award.


In more detail, the project centers around the theory of automorphic forms, a branch of number theory which studies natural numbers through symmetries. The theory of L-functions and its special values is of particular interest in this subject. The main goal is to apply various techniques from representation theory and harmonic analysis to prove identities linking special values of L-functions to other objects, e.g. period integrals, or heights of special cycles on Shimura varieties. More concretely the PI will study the following conjectures: (1) Gan--Gross--Prasad conjectures and its arithmetic variant; (2)Guo--Jacquet conjecture on linear periods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project is about automorphic forms, which are functions with a lot of symmetries. It has found important applications to math, physics, and other science subjects.

 

Intellectual merit:

The PI published five papers during the grant cycle. The common theme of these papers are the period integrals of the automorphic forms. It exploits novel applications of the techniques of relative trace formulae and theta correspondences.

For the relative trace formula technique, the PI used it to prove some epsilon dichotomy conjecture of Prasad and Takloo-Bighash in a large number of cases. Collaborating with Wei Zhang (MIT), the author also devised new relative trace formulae to cover many more cases of the conjecture. The new relative trace formulae have the potential of proving the conjecture in full generality.

For the technique of theta correspondences, the author proved a conjecture of Gan, Gross and Prasad whose origin goes back to mid-1990. Along the way the PI proved or enhanced many classical results on theta correspondences.

 

Broader impacts:

The PI has used some problems from this proposal or their derived forms for his current graduate and undergraduate students. The PI is one of the scientific organizers and the main local organizer of the renowned Arizona Winter School (AWS). AWS 2022 was on the subject of automorphic forms, and some results the author obtained during this grant cycle appeared in this AWS.

It is also very likely that new questions and speculations will arise in the course of studying questions raised by this proposal and will stimulate future research programs in the field.
